results.title: The Harp in the South
results.brief_description: Television dramatisation of Ruth Park’s novel following the life and times of a poor Irish Australian family in the aftermath of World War II. This is the poignant saga of the poverty-stricken Darcys of number 12 1/2 Plymouth Street in Surrey Hills - a Sydney slum with its complement of gangs, brothels and sly grog shops.

results.title: Halloween (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: John Carpenter, Debra Hill and Falcon Film
results.brief_description: John Carpenter’s much imitated Halloween defined the eighties stalk and slash genre, spawning inferior copies like the Friday the 13th series (including six sequels of it’s own) and for a time making star Jamie Lee Curtis into the premium ‘scream queen’. Later on the conventions of the genre were cleverly re-invented for a nineties audience by director Wes Craven and writer Kevin Williamson in Scream, which pays direct homage to Halloween. John Carpenter opens his film with an unnerving point of view shot of the young psychotic Michael Myers brutally stabbing his teenage sister to death on Halloween night. Flash forward to Halloween 15 years later and Michael has escaped the mental institution he has been locked up in. Meanwhile shy, virginal teenager Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis) and her girlfriends are preparing for Halloween, unaware of the menace that lurks in their quiet suburban community. Carpenter makes great use of the sparse, atmospheric music score (which he also composed) and uses to maximum creepy effect the white mask Michael Myers wears throughout the film. The film also established the classic horror genre rule if your a sexually active teenager, you die! Also staring: Donald Pleasence, P.J. Soles, Tony Moran.

results.title: Getting it right
results.creator_credit: FM-TV Australia, Equal Employment Opportunity Trust
results.brief_description: Four scenarios portraying realistic situations in recruitment, counselling, feedback, assessing potential and staff retention. Discusses: job application assumptions, managing subordinates, problems faced by personnel in accepting geographical transfer, ethnicity as a disadvantage in career development, why companies can lose women in management or with management potential.

results.title: Three approaches to psychotherapy I. Part 3
results.creator_credit: Everett L. Shostrom and Psychological Films
results.brief_description: Dr. Ellis challenges Gloria’s absolutes - her “awfullising” and “catastrophising” - that make her feel so unhappy with herself and that sabotage her relationships with others. He teaches her that the irrational things she says to herself causes her negative feelings and her consequent behaviour. Gloria begins to discover that she can correct her irrational thoughts and reverse her negative feelings and behaviours.

results.title: Relationships
results.brief_description: Starting, ending and maintaining relationships is never easy. Peter Quarry leads couples through the minefield and discusses: What attracts people to each other, how to turn a friendship into something deeper, how to keep a relationship alive, conflict, resolution, knowing when to quit, being single and enjoying it.

results.title: Green Winter
results.brief_description: Elda Hartley set out to make a film about ageing and realised, as a senior citizen herself, she would make a good subject for her film. She candidly examines her own life - “Its not death that bothers me - it’s the deterioration of my mind and body.” Elda sorts through her experience with other cultures and religions, illustrating certain points from many films, and takes an intimate look at her relationship with her husband, Irving, whose failing health demands her complete attention. A personal, yet comprehensive approach to the issues of aging.

results.title: Eight in the 80's
results.brief_description: Showcases eight interesting and innovative films made on the low budget medium of Super 8. Because of the gauge’s low cost and extreme flexibility the filmmakers using Super 8 have a freedom that allows them to create genuinely exciting and rich works, ranging from diaristic experimental films to straighter narrative dramas through to absurdist, surrealistic comedies.

results.title: On your marks it's bright sparks. - Volume 2.
results.creator_credit: Jeff Gale, Mark Lamprell and Pru Donovan
results.brief_description: Planes, Trains, Boats and Cars: Sparky, Amy and Alex discover floating bikes, underwater boats, trucks without drivers, trains without trucks, cars that become boats and planes that become helicopters. But can Alex really turn his BMX bike into an excavator to drill a hole to China? “Water, Water, Everywhere”: Planet Earth should be called Planet Water says Sparky, as he flies Amy and Alex around the world to see why. From the Amazon River to the River Nile and even Antarctica, Amy and Alex see how water is a wonderful gift - to be used, enjoyed and shared by everyone.

results.title: Musical Tales
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Elizabeth Bennett and John Hosier
results.brief_description: This beautifully animated puppet film presents four of your favourite stories set to the great classical music of Tschaikovsky, Stravinsky and Delibes. Featurees “The Nutcracker and the Mouse King”, “Petrushka”, “Coppelia” and “Sleeping Beauty”.
